title: Undefined error when browserifying Brython
body:
From https://github.com/brython-dev/brython/issues/1351:

I'm hoping to load Brython into the client side code through Browserify, so that it can be bundled together with all other dependencies into one file. This seems to work well with all other NPM packages I've tried, so it's surprising that it doesn't work with Brython.

deps.js

```javascript
// This file and all its required dependencies will be bundled by Browserify
// to make them available to scripts in index.html. This lets us use NPM
// packages for client side scripts.

// Make _require() available to the front end to load the modules listed
// in the present file. Note: We would usually assign to `window.require`,
// however, this seems to cause an infinite recursion for Brython.
window._require = require

// Require NPM packages to be used by the front end, so that they will
// be included in the bundle.
require('brython')
require('tone')
```

index.html

```html
<html>
<body>

<!-- Load our dependencies. -->
<script type="text/javascript" src="bundle.js"></script>

<!-- Activate Brython for the script below. -->
<script type="text/javascript">
Tone = _require('tone')  // This works.
brython = _require('brython')
brython({debug: 1})  // This doesn't work.
</script>

<!-- Use the dependencies. -->
<script type="text/python">
print('Hello world!')
from browser import window
path = 'https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/Tonejs/Tone.js/examples/audio/505/snare.ogg'
Tone = window._require('tone')
Tone.Player.new(path).connect(Tone.Volume.new(-12).toDestination()).start()
</script>

</body>
</html>
```

Comands

```sh
mkdir example && example
npm init
npm install brython
npm install browserify
npm install tone
npx browserify deps.js -o bundle.js
google-chrome index.html
```

Developer console output

```
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'name' of undefined
```

title: Export multiple dependencies separate from custom code
body:
I'm running into an issue and would like to ask if I'm using Browserify correctly to get an idea of how to further debug this. I need to separate my frontend code from its npm dependencies, because I'm building a code editor that should give the user access to the libraries:

index.html:

```html
<script src="deps.js"></script>
<script src="script.js"></script>
```

script.js:

```js
var ReconnectingWebSocket = require('reconnecting-websocket');
var sharedb = require('sharedb/lib/client');
var socket = new ReconnectingWebSocket('ws://' + window.location.host);
var connection = sharedb.Connection(socket);
// ...
```

I generate deps.js using Browserify with multiple `-r` flags:

```sh
npx browserify -o deps.js -r reconnecting-websocket -r sharedb/lib/client -r rich-text -r quill -r quill-cursors -r tinycolor2 -r bson-objectid

Serving the static files and viewing them in Chrome show this error in the developer console:

deps.js:12085 Uncaught TypeError: this.bindToSocket is not a function

I'm wondering whether this is a problem with ShareDB, with my way of bundling its client submodule via `-r sharedb/lib/client`, or with using the `-r` flag in Browserify in general. Thanks for your insights!

title: __dirname is incorrect when browserifying to a subdirectory
body:
This issue might be related to  #1919 

## How to reproduce
Create a simple project:
***./test.json:***
```json
{
    "test": "test"
}
```

***./src/index.js:***
```js
const path = require("path");
console.log(require(path.join(__dirname, "..", "test.json"))["test"]);
```

Browserify it
```sh
npx browserify --node --debug ./src/index.js -o ./lib/index.js
```

## Expected behavior
The generated `__dirname` should either be `./src` or `./lib`.

## Actual behavior
***./lib/index.js:***
```js
(function (__dirname){
const path = require("path");

console.log(require(path.join(__dirname, "..", "test.json"))["test"]);
}).call(this,require("path").join(__dirname,"src"))
```

The generated `__dirname` points to `path.join(__dirname, "src")` which equals `./lib/src/index.js`.

title: Sourcemap-Paths are incorrect when browserifying to a subdirectory
body:
Hey Guys
When I create a pretty simple setup ("src/index.js" with `console.log("Hello World")` in it).
I found out that the created source-maps are incorrect.

## How to reproduce
Create a simple index.js-file:
***src/index.js:***
```js
console.log("Hello World");
```

Browserify it
```sh
npx browserify --debug ./src/index.js -o ./lib/index.js
```

## Expected behavior
The inline source-map in `./lib/index.js` should contain a relative path to `./src/index.js` which is: `../src/index.js`.

## Actual behavior
The path inside the source-map is incorrect: `src/index.js`

title: Support custom names for "browser" field resolution
body:
I'm packaging WebTorrent so it can be used in a Chrome App environment. This is for the built-in torrent support in [Brave Browser](https://brave.com).

The "browser" field is automatically used during bundling, but for Chrome Apps I'd like to do different substitutions than for normal browser. Specifically, I'd like to use e.g. `chrome-net` instead of `net` since Chrome Apps have access to raw sockets, but normal browsers do not. Therefore, I cannot add this substitution to the `'browser'` field without breaking the normal browser build.

What I really need is a way to specify what field name in `package.json` should be used for the browser field resolution, with `"browser"` being the default.

Fortunately, [`browser-resolve`](https://github.com/defunctzombie/node-browser-resolve) already support such an option! The [`browser` option](https://github.com/defunctzombie/node-browser-resolve#resolveid-opts-cb) allows the user to select which property name to use from `package.json`. It defaults to `"browser"`.

I'd like to update the existing config option `browserField` to accept a string value, e.g. `{ browserField: 'chromeapp' }` for this exact purpose. Currently, this config option is only used to disable the browser field entirely, e.g.`{ browserField: false }`, so we can add a new string option relatively easily. I think this is cleanest.

What do folks think?

This lets us get the latest and best improvements.

Update version of events bundled
body: Browserify currently uses [`events@^2.0.0`](https://github.com/browserify/browserify/blob/cfd3af23f6383bb5899dbb5e39beb7834b042d85/package.json#L41), but `events` has an updated version [`3.0.0`](https://github.com/Gozala/events/releases/tag/v3.0.0) to support the introduction of the [`off()`](https://nodejs.org/api/events.html#events_emitter_off_eventname_listener) method introduced in Node v10. Is there a way to override the version of `events` that browserify uses for bundling? I also think browserify should bump the version used on `package.json`, but note that `events@3.0.0` no longer supports ES5 shims out of the box.

title: Certain package.json browser field values break extension-less require()s
body:
Here's a minimal example demonstrating the problem: https://gist.github.com/nathan/6fc02adb0745e71f51836a374dcf1011

Essentially, a `browser` field which maps from a filename with an extension to a filename without an extension (e.g., `"./default.js": "./browser"`) breaks `require()`s without an extension (e.g., `require("./default")`). Using `--no-bf`, both `require("./default")` and `require("./default.js")` have the same effect. However, without it, only `require("./default.js")` resolves to `./browser.js`; `require("./default")` produces an error (`ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat '…/browser'`):
```sh
$ browserify --no-bf main-with-ext | node
default
$ browserify --no-bf main | node
default
$ browserify main-with-ext | node
browser
$ browserify main | node
Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat '…/browser'
```

I ran into this implementing tests for the `browser` field in my bundler. I doubt it's very common in real usage but figured I'd file an issue here. By comparison, Webpack accepts both `require("./default")` and `require("./default.js")` in this situation, and they both resolve to `./browser.js`:

```sh
$ webpack main-with-ext.js -o out.js && node out.js
…
browser
$ webpack main.js -o out.js && node out.js
…
browser

title: `browserField: false` makes browserify ignore the transform option
Cannot find module './aes.asm' from '/Users.../openpgp/dist'
body:
Hi, I'm not sure if its best if I post this on here or on the openpgpjs issues page.
I am able to run some javascript code using `node mycode.js` but I'm trying to incorporate this logic into a Rails web app (specifically on the client side) and so I started looking at browserify to be able to address not being able to require(...) on the client-side.

However, I'm getting an error that I'm a bit confused about:

title: Fix up code so NPM audit doesn't trigger alerts & clean up tests that used deprecated Buffer calls
body:
Version 16.2.3 of browserify reports 15 vulnerabilities, 14 moderate and 1 high.
I have traced all of these back to two devDependencies and 3 of the unit tests.
The dev dependencies are concat-stream and tap; they just require upversioning.
The unit tests required small modification to make safe calls to Buffer in the Buffer.from() style.

I am opening a corresponding pull request #1899

To replicate:
clone down repo and checkout 16.2.3 or master
npm i install --package-lock-only

Try out my pull request to get to zero vulnerabilities and all tests passing with 1 test skipped (evil json test which only runs in windows environment, which I don't have access to).

title: Changing package.json to use concat-stream "^2.0.0" and tap "^12.5.3"…
body:
… to remove npm audit security warngings; updating tests to use Buffer.from() where appropriate to remove deprecation warnings in tests

Fixes #1900.

title: Shallow run
body:
Is there any way to run browserify on a file/stdin, skipping all bundling steps and just applying a transform/plugin? That would enable browserify for other bundling systems, like [ncc](https://github.com/zeit/ncc) or [rollup](https://github.com/lautis/rollup-plugin-browserify-transform) as a transform CLI tool. _ncc_, for example, is incapable of handling glslify.

There is [browserify-single-file](https://ghub.io/browserify-single-file) package for that purpose, which seems to be broken. That can be fixed to match the current API, but that will be outdated with the next browserify release, also that emulates just a part of browserify API, which likely makes most of the plugins unavailable for it.

A flag `--shallow` (`--no-bundle`, `--bypass` or alike) would be a natural extension of `--bare` / `--node`, and similar by output to `--list` or `--deps`.

@goto-bus-stop would you consider this a good feature?

title: Using --list with --require gives unexpected results
body:
As per the documentation, `--list` seems to be a good option for use with Makefiles. I have noticed that with `--require`, however, the module name is used instead of its file path. This means that for a Makefile the dependencies are not properly established. For example:

```sh
# setup
$ mkdir -p /tmp/test ; cd /tmp/test ; npm i browserify

$ browserify --list --require path
/tmp/test/node_modules/process/browser.js
path
```

Notice how "path" appears instead of the full file path compared with:

```sh
$ echo "require('path')" | browserify --list -
/tmp/test/node_modules/process/browser.js
/tmp/test/node_modules/path-browserify/index.js
/tmp/test/_stream_0.js
```

Seems like a bug?

title: Can't parse optional catch binding when `require` variable exists
Can't parse for-await statements

Could you support for-await statements?

```
for await (const _ of (async function* () {})()) {
    ^
ParseError: Unexpected token
```

title: Use native Object.assign instead of xtend
body:
[xtend](https://github.com/Raynos/xtend) can easily be replaced with [Object.assign](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Object/assign)

This reduce the dependencies and possible also avoid duplicated versions where some package don't use the same version range for the xtend package

```js
// immutable
Object.assign({}, a, b)

// mutable
Object.assign(a, b)
```

title: Piping into browserify doesn't work
Browserify failing to apply transformations to monorepo package
body:
I am unable to run browserify (via gulp-browserify) with a babelify transform on Javascript source files.  The code lives inside a monorepo that has the following structure:

```
the-project
  packages
    library
      index.js
    app
      main.js
```

`app/main.js` contains the following code:
```js
// @flow

import { test } from "libzotero";

test(1, 2, 3);
console.log("done.");
```

`library/index.js` contains simply:
```js
// @flow

function test(...args: Array<any>): number {
  return args.length;
}

export { test };
```

Running browserify from within `app` results in the following:
```
packages/app $ ../../node_modules/.bin/browserify -t babelify main.js
SyntaxError: /path/to/project/node_modules/libzotero/index.js: Unexpected token, expected ")" (3:21)

  1 | // @flow
  2 | 
> 3 | function test(...args: Array<any>): number {
    |                      ^
  4 |   console.log("TEST! Args:", args);
  5 |   return args.length;
  6 | }
    at Parser.raise (/path/to/project/node_modules/@babel/core/node_modules/@babel/parser/lib/index.js:3939:15)
    at Parser.unexpected (/path/to/project/node_modules/@babel/core/node_modules/@babel/parser/lib/index.js:5248:16)
    at Parser.expect (/path/to/project/node_modules/@babel/core/node_modules/@babel/parser/lib/index.js:5236:28)
    at Parser.parseBindingList (/path/to/project/node_modules/@babel/core/node_modules/@babel/parser/lib/index.js:5529:14)
    at Parser.parseFunctionParams (/path/to/project/node_modules/@babel/core/node_modules/@babel/parser/lib/index.js:7833:24)
    at Parser.parseFunction (/path/to/project/node_modules/@babel/core/node_modules/@babel/parser/lib/index.js:7820:10)
    at Parser.parseFunctionStatement (/path/to/project/node_modules/@babel/core/node_modules/@babel/parser/lib/index.js:7476:17)
    at Parser.parseStatementContent (/path/to/project/node_modules/@babel/core/node_modules/@babel/parser/lib/index.js:7169:21)
    at Parser.parseStatement (/path/to/project/node_modules/@babel/core/node_modules/@babel/parser/lib/index.js:7145:17)
    at Parser.parseBlockOrModuleBlockBody (/path/to/project/node_modules/@babel/core/node_modules/@babel/parser/lib/index.js:7696:23)
```

It seems that browserify is ignoring babel(ify) transformations on any source files in `library`.  What can be done about this?

title: Error when bundling results in unowned resources
body:
I'm trying to use the Browserify API in a small CLI tool that takes a list of files as input. When Browserify cannot open a file, it correctly emits an error on the bundler, but unfortunately there are some unowned resources that prevent the Node.js process from exiting.

Using the [`leaked-handles` package](https://github.com/Raynos/leaked-handles) I can see three handles:

```text
no of handles 3

tcp stream { fd: 20,
  readable: false,
  writable: true,
  address: {},
  serverAddr: null }

tcp stream { fd: 22,
  readable: false,
  writable: true,
  address: {},
  serverAddr: null }

unknown handle Timer {
  _list:
   TimersList {
     _idleNext:
      Timeout {
        _called: false,
        _idleTimeout: 1,
        _idlePrev: [Circular],
        _idleNext: [Circular],
        _idleStart: 5294,
        _onTimeout: [Function: resolve],
        _timerArgs: undefined,
        _repeat: null,
        _destroyed: false,
        [Symbol(unrefed)]: false,
        [Symbol(asyncId)]: 3367,
        [Symbol(triggerId)]: 3366 },
     _idlePrev:
      Timeout {
        _called: false,
        _idleTimeout: 1,
        _idlePrev: [Circular],
        _idleNext: [Circular],
        _idleStart: 5294,
        _onTimeout: [Function: resolve],
        _timerArgs: undefined,
        _repeat: null,
        _destroyed: false,
        [Symbol(unrefed)]: false,
        [Symbol(asyncId)]: 3367,
        [Symbol(triggerId)]: 3366 },
     _unrefed: false,
     msecs: 1,
     _timer: [Circular] } }
```

This is my code:

```js
const b = browserify()

b.add('library.js') // this file exists
b.add('foobar.js') // this file is missing

const stream = b.bundle()
const output = fs.createWriteStream('test-output.js')

stream.pipe(output)
stream.on('error', err => output.destroy(err))

await new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
  output.on('error', reject)
  output.on('close', resolve)
})
```

I can see that the last `Promise` that I await here is correctly rejected by an error that flows from `stream.on 'error'` to `output.on 'error'` via the `destroy` method on `output`.

title: Use the latest punycode(1.3.2)
Corrupted bundle produced because of name incorrect path resolution when using external and require combined.
body:
Browserify version: 16.2.2
Here is minimal test: https://github.com/motz-art/browserify-name-issue
Fill free to include the test into Browserify test suite.

Because of `"pdfkit"` package is requested in `require` call, when Browserify processes `labels` (line 747 of browserify/index.js file) `row.file` equals `"pdfkit"` resulting in `rfile` variable equals `"/page"` that is confused with `"page"` module which is externalized and remapped (in line 753) to `"/page"`.

At the end all this produces invalid bundle that results in `'Cannot find module '/page''` Error (Error code: `MODULE_NOT_FOUND`)

On my opinion there are two issues:
1. Each included module/file should have full path resolved (when possible). And this path should be used to calculate `rfile` variable.
2. Each dependency should have full path resolved including file extension.

title: Output bundle as an ES6 module
body:
I want to expose my bundle (a module I wrote) as an ES6 module (using `export default ...`). Can Browserify do this? It would be nice to have as an option/flag.

Although I personally want to bundle all of my module's scripts and dependencies into a single file, I don't want to force the developer who uses my module to also use a script bundler (especially during development/debugging).

If a developer wants to build a real ES6 app (not Babelified one) which imports ES6 modules from the front end then I would like my module's bundle to be compatible with this workflow.

title: Using --no-bundle-external and NODE_PATH
body:
Hi, I'm trying to create a single bundle for a node app. I want to omit node_modules from the budle, so I use `--no-bundle-external`. And I'm using `NODE_PATH=common` to avoid a lot of `require('../../..`

Unfortunately it omits everything from `common/` from the bundle. Is there a way to get it to just omit `node_modules` and native node libs (fs, path, etc.) but include my app's `common` files?

The only way I've got it to work so far is to manually list everything to exclude with `-u foo -u bar ...` which is not ideal. Any other options?

title: Bundle js without browser-pack
Unexpected end of input
body:
**What's happening?**

gulp and/or Browserify are compiling incomplete js, resulting in an `Unexpected end of input` console error on page load.

**What did you expect to happen?**

To have functional js at the end of the compiling process.

**Environment details**

I'm using gulp and Browserify to compile Vue.js components. I experienced this issue previously with `axios`, but was able to resolve it by explicitly exposing `axios`. This time, it's impacting any dependency that I try to bring into my app. Here's some sample code:

test.app.js
```js
import Vue from 'vue';
import VueStrap from '../../vue/vue-strap';

Vue.component('vSelect', VueStrap.select);

window.DashboardApp = new Vue({
  el: '#dashboard',
});
```

gulpfile.js
```js
var gulp        = require('gulp');
var browserify  = require('browserify');
var vueify      = require('vueify');
var transform   = require('vinyl-transform');
var source      = require('vinyl-source-stream');
var sass        = require('gulp-sass');
var sourcemaps  = require('gulp-sourcemaps');
var babelify    = require('babelify');
var glob        = require('glob');
var rename      = require('gulp-rename');
var rev         = require('gulp-rev');

gulp.task('test', function() {
  glob('./js/vue-mini-apps/test/*.app.js', function(err, files) {
    if (err) {
      gutil.log(gutil.colors.red('Glob error:'),err);
    }
    //browserify each file
    var tasks = files.map(function(entry) {
      return browserify(entry, {debug:true})
        .transform(babelify, {presets: ['es2015'], plugins: ["transform-runtime", "transform-async-to-generator"]})
        .bundle()
        .pipe(source(entry))
        //determine file name from file path
        .pipe(rename('test-bundle.js'))
        .pipe(gulp.dest('./js/vue-mini-apps/dist'));
    });
  });
});
```

package.json
```js

  "author": "self",

  },

```

Environment versions:
```bash
node -v
v10.6.0

npm -v 
6.1.0

uname -a
Darwin USER 17.7.0 Darwin Kernel Version 17.7.0: Thu Jun 21 22:53:14 PDT 2018; root:xnu-4570.71.2~1/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64
```

**Attempted resolutions**

- rm'ed `node_modules`
- ran `npm cache verify`
- `npm install`
- `npm update`
- brought in a different, known working `package.json`
- created a separate file (the one included here is the test file I created)
- added `.require('./node_modules/[package-name]/[path-to-source]', {expose: '[package-name]'})` immediately after the `browserify()` call
- changed `import [Package-Name] from '[package-name]'` to `const [Package-Name] = require('[package-name]');`

I've exhausted the extent of what I know how to do that's fixed this in the past.

I'm not sure if this is considered a support channel, and understand if you need to close this issue due to not being a real 'issue' with Browserify. Any assistance on this matter would be greatly appreciated, as it's been plaguing me for months on and off, and this time it's utterly broken. Thank you!

title: URL is not a constructor
body:
---

version: 16.2.2
browser: Chrome 67.0.3396.99

---

Wrong export using WhatWG URL from builtin module `url`:

```javascript
const {URL} = require('url');
const url = new URL('http://localhost/');
```

This code works as expected in node. But produce Error in browser:

```
Error: URL is not a constructor
```

And it looks like the cause of this error is outdated [url](https://npmjs.com/package/url) package.
